Segal',* Institute of Physical Chemistry of the Romanian Academy, Splaiul lndependenlei 202, Bucharest 77208, Romania Received 16 December 1992; accepted 31 May 1994 Abstract A new model for single-route, steady-state reactions on nonuniform catalytic surfaces is presented. Giving up some assumptions of the Temkin model and making use of a common mean-value theorem result in the introduction of the concept of kinetic insensitivity. The model rigorously accounts for the existence of a broad class of reactions the evolution of which is accurately described by "classical kinetics" (derived on ideal, uniform surfaces). The connections with structure sensitivity/insensitivity are examined in relation with the frequently invoked effect of surface restructuring. The application to two-step sequences leads to the classical Temkin model (as a particular case) and reveals some of its shortcomings, not yet reported. Keywords: Kinetic insensitivity; Non-uniformity; Single-route reactions; Steady-state kinetics; Surfaces 1. Introduction The concept of nonuniform catalytical surfaces, introduced by Temkin [ 1-3], is founded on the experimental evidence that the heat of adsorption varies with coverage and embodies two complementary explanations [ 4 ] of this fact: (i) the "biographic" nonuniformity, formerly called "heterogeneity", dating back to Taylor's theory of active centres [ 5 ] ; (ii) the "induced" nonuniformity, essentially due to adsorbate-adsorbate [6] and adsorbate-adsorbent [7] interactions. Whatever the microscopic reasons, a nonuniform catalytic surface could be pictured at a "mesoscopic" level as a collection of sites (active centres) with gradually * Corresponding author. Sites with the same activity could be grouped in ensembles [8] with clear physical support (e.g., different crystal planes exposed), as in the "homotactic patch" model [ 9,10] , or have a random geometrical distribution. Although nonuniformity is generally accepted, at least in connection with industrial catalytic reactions, the single attempt to include it quantitatively in catalytic kinetics seems to be that of Temkin [ 1-3] . The Temkin model (TM) is restricted essentially to two-step catalytic sequences and involves some daring assumptions which make it convenient and extremely versatile. It was successfully applied to some important processes by the author [ 3 ] , Kiperman [ 11 ] and several members of the Russian school and largely discussed by Boudart [ 8,12] and more recently by Ichikawa [ 13,14 ] . From the kinetic point of view, reactions on nonuniform surfaces are expected to exhibit equations differing from the "classical" ones [ 4 ] , established on uniform surfaces and well-known as Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) rate laws [ 15 ] . This indeed happens as most kinetic data on "real" catalysts are described by power rate laws, extensively used in chemical engineering. The major success of the TM was just the prediction of such laws, e.g., for ammonia synthesis [6]. However, in many cases one can find a classical model (neglecting nonuniformity) yielding a kinetic equation with similar capabilities of fitting experimental data as the empirical power rate law. This was the source of an old controversy between Boudart [ 17,4] and Weller [ 18,19], the first defending classical kinetics, the second, the empirical one. In a more recent examination of this matter [4] Boudart appeals to the notion of structure sensitivity /insensitivity (SS/SI) introduced by himself [ 20 ] and closely related to nonuniformity. In general the reactions found to be sensitive to the modifications of the catalyst surface structure are governed by power rate laws, while SI ones (the turnover rate of which remains unaltered at such modifications) obey classical kinetics [ 4,8 ] . Clearly, structure changes result in nonuniformity (site-distribution) ones, so one should expect structure sensitivity to be a general phenomenon, whereas many experimental facts seem to show the contrary [ 21 ] . Some older explanations of the puzzling structure insensitivity quoted in [4] are: low site-multiplicity required for the rate-determining step, surface reconstruction, extractive chemisorption, formation of a catalytic metal-alkyl overlayer. An additional one advanced by the author [4] is that SI reactions are run at high coverages when biographic nonuniformity is masked and, moreover, classical rate equations are rigorously valid. However, Ichikawa [13,14] outlined the fact that SI is possible even at low coverages, his argument being related to the nonuniformity through the older formulation of the TM [ 1,2,11,12] and thus sharing the same shortcoming: the lack of an explicit site-distribution function accounting for nonuniformity (In fact a constant one is implicitly assumed thus involving an "evenly nonuniform" surface [ 3 ]) . V.T. Popa, E. Segal /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 94 (1994) 47-69 49 Several objections to Boudart's point of view were raised by Kiperman et al. [ 22 ] and carefully reviewed in Weller's recent contribution [ 23 ] . These include, in addition to the above-mentioned idea that SI reactions are not necessarily taking place on highly covered surfaces, the fact that they are not bound to classical kinetic descriptions. For a broad group of reactions, cited in [ 22 ] , most of them investigated by members of the Russian and Bulgarian schools, the best fit to experimental rate data is given by equations that are neither the LHHW nor the power law type. Moreover, the derivation of such equations is possible on basis of nonuniform surface activity. An alternative approach invoked in Boudart's response [24] is due to Corma et al. [ 25 ] which tested 12 rate equations (derived for Langmuir, Temkin and Freundlich adsorption) on 19 reported studies for which detailed kinetic data were available. However this procedure is restricted to catalytic kinetics with (quasi) equilibrated adsorption [26], a particular case which neither most heterogeneously catalysed reactions nor the Temkin model itself are not confined to. A likely microscopic argument seems to be Somorjai's concept of "flexible surface" [ 27,28 ] : experimental evidence of surface restructuring through adsorbate-adsorbent interactions on chemisorption time scale (10-6 s) are thought to be the result of an "induced uniformity" of the initial biographically nonuniform surface and thus of SI reactions. This picture is clearly the opposite of the older one of induced nonuniformity. Moreover, it affects one of the basic TM assumptions: the analogy between the adsorption equilibrium and the steady-state reaction on a certain catalytic surface. This means that a catalyst exhibiting strong nonuniformity at the adsorption equilibrium of a reactant should behave similarly while performing some reaction of the same substance (This led Temkin to the use of only two types of site distributions, i.e., the constant and exponential ones related to the Temkin and Freundlich empirical isotherms, respectively). In contrast, in Somorjai's view surface restructuring caused by strong chemisorption of reactants could erase (just as some other phenomena quoted in [4] ) the biographic~nonuniformity while creating the (initially absent) active sites for the reaction. It seems that describing reactive nonuniformity in terms of site distributions derived from adsorption equilibria is not generally valid. Removing this constraint and some other assumptions of the TM enables the construction of a new, more general model revealing the connections between surface nonuniformity, structure sensitivity and kinetics for the rather broad class of multi-step, single-route reactions. This new model reduces to the TM as a particular case for two-step mechanisms while revealing some inconsistencies, not yet reported, of the classical Temkin approach. 2. Conclusions Including of the surface nonuniformity into multi-step, single-route catalytic reactions was achieved with no principial difficulties. The model thus elaborated, although seemingly hopeless for analytical solutions, leads to some general conclusions through the application of a mean-value theorem: Single-route reactions generally exhibit kinetic insensitivity, i.e., they are correctly described by classical kinetic equations in spite of the nonuniform catalytic activity. The new model accounts for instances when, due to restructuring processes, the biographic nonuniformity is erased. Structure sensitivity/ insensitivity is, in principle, allowed within both the above situations. For two-step sequences the model reduces to the Temkin one, reveals some of its not yet reported inconsistencies, and offers a means of correction: Classical TM generally overestimates the overall rate and in some limiting cases erroneously predicts both kinetic equations and overall coverages; for these the corrected solutions are easily derived. If the original assumptions of the TM hold, kinetic equations of power law type are not a consequence of the nonuniformity, but of the particular way in which the classical models deals with it, i.e. of the specific simplifications involved. In catalytic processes the evolution of which can be described only by power or more complicated rate laws, mechanistic multiplicity is to be suspected in the first place. However, if such processes are single-route, then the associated site-distribution is most probably changing within the experimental (composition and temperature) investigated range.
